awd_titl_txt: ABI Innovation: A Metabolomics Toolkit for NMR and Mass Spectrometry
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Advances in Biological Informatics in the Division of Biological Infrastructure, Professor Robert Powers and his research group at the University of Nebraska - Lincoln will further develop their MVAPACK software toolkit that analyzes data generated in metabolomics research. Metabolomics is the study of the chemical signatures of the small molecules, like sugars, that are the products of biological processes. Metabolite fingerprints reveal a great deal about the recent activities occurring in biological samples. Knowing how organisms respond to their surroundings gives important leads to understanding events in fields like plant biology and agriculture, environmental and water quality studies, and human health research into nutrition or diseases. The chemical fingerprints are generated using two different technologies, called nuclear magnetic resonance and mass spectrometry. The results can be very complex and difficult to merge. This means the challenges for data analysis are also high, and include requirements to develop new approaches, like multivariate statistical methods. This proposal aims to produce software tools that will extract the most possible information from the data, including data format conversion, preprocessing, validation, significance testing, visualization, and metabolite identification at defined levels of confidence. The MVAPACK toolkit will enable important, currently unavailable data processing functions in the form of freely available and open source software modules, with an impact on data quality, sharing, information content resulting in deeper biological insights from studies that include metabolite profiling.  


 
 During the award period, this research project will further enhance the MVAPACK metabolomics toolkit by including additional and urgently needed capabilities. Such improvements will include adding features to load and process liquid chromatography (LC)-MS, gas chromatography(GC)-MS and multidimensional datasets; to expand capabilities to integrate multiple datasets for chemometrics; and to automate metabolite identification, which is one of the more challenging and time-consuming aspects of metabolomics. This work will employ, among other approaches, graph theory, covariance NMR, back-scaled pseudospectral loadings, and a combined NMR and MS approach to facilitate the accurate and rapid assignment of metabolites from complex biological samples. Overall, these efforts will lead to an improved MVAPACK software package (http://bionmr.unl.edu/mvapack.php) for the metabolomics scientific community that will enhance the information content, utility, and ease of processing and combining various types of NMR and MS datasets.

por.por_cntn:
Metabolomics strives to identify and quantify all small molecular-weight chemicals or metabolites in a biological sample that ranges from cell cultures to whole organisms; and may include anything from biofluids like blood or urine, to plants or foods. In this regard, metabolomics has significantly benefited a diversity of scientific enquiries in fields that includes agriculture, energy, environment, nutrition, human health, and has helped answer innumerous fundamental questions about biological systems. Despite the exponential growth of metabolomics, the field still faces several challenges. Of paramount concern is the multidisciplinary nature of metabolomics that requires expertise in analytical chemistry, bioinformatics, chemometrics, cellular biology, chromatography, clinical research, instrumental analysis (i.e., nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR), mass spectrometry (MS)), metabolism, programming, statistics, etc. Obtaining proficiency in all these skills is a daunting task.

The proper application of statistics and data processing is particularly challenging, which often leads to erroneous reports in the scientific literature. Worse yet is the fact that a data processing pipeline is typically comprised of a disjointed collection of academic and commercial software that usually don?t work well together and commonly requires manual intervention. To address these and other issues, we developed our MVAPACK toolkit (Figure 1) that provides a single, flexible platform for the processing and analysis of metabolomics data. MVAPACK provides a framework by which both new and established data handling methods may be tested and adopted.

MVAPACK was initially developed for processing NMR datasets comprised of 1D 1H NMR spectra. The central goal of the ABI Innovation: A Metabolomics Toolkit for NMR and Mass Spectrometry (1660921) project was to further enhance the capabilities of our MVAPACK software by integrating multiple datasets for chemometrics; and to automate metabolite identification.

The newest version of MVPACK (version 2.2) provides a complete spectral processing, data matrix preprocessing and statistical methodology necessary for the routine and accurate analysis of both NMR and MS-based metabolomics data. MVAPACK is freely accessible to academic or not-for-profit investigators through our website (http://bionmr.unl.edu/mvapack.php), webserver (https://mvapack.unl.edu), or NMRBox (www.nmrbox.org/). To date, there are 649 registered users and 752 downloads through our website and 102 external users with 403 unique usages through NMRBox.

A primary goal of a metabolomics experiment is to identify the metabolites present in a complex mixture, which routinely contains hundreds to thousands of compounds. Our enhancements to MVAPACK directly addressed this need. We developed an algorithm to automate metabolite assignments from 1D 1H NMR spectra that significantly outperformed existing software packages, which routinely relies on manual intervention. We also developed a new NMR experiment (decoupled HMBC) that when combined with our covariance matrix software produces a pseudo-NMR spectrum that provides a complete carbon-carbon network that uniquely defines a metabolite and is impractical to obtain experimentally. This will improve the speed and accuracy of metabolite assignments.

NMR peaks move due to differences in pH, temperature, ionic strength, and mixture composition. Consequentially, annotating an NMR spectrum of a complex mixture by matching it to a collection of reference NMR spectra of individual metabolites has a high false-positive and false negative rate because of peak mismatches. To improve the accuracy of our algorithm to automate metabolite assignments from 1D 1H NMR spectra, we cataloged NMR peak variability by experimentally collecting hundreds of NMR spectra over a range of pHs, temperature, and metabolite type.     

A complete LC-MS data processing pipeline was implemented into MVAPACK, which makes MVAPACK the only metabolomics software that can process NMR and MS data individually or combined. We also created the first synthetic LC-MS dataset for validating and benchmarking metabolomics software, which allowed us to compare the performance of MVAPACK to MSDIal and XCMS (popular MS software). MVAPACK exhibited the best overall performance. We also updated and improved our 2D NMR data processing pipeline, added additional software and algorithms to process and visualize metabolomics datasets, and released a MVAPACK web server to enhance to accessibility of MVAPACK to the non-expert.

MVAPACK provides a foundation for investigating and reporting best practices for the application of NMR, MS, and statistical methods to metabolomics. Thus, an important outcome of this project was the publication of several impactful methods and review articles that defines these best practices and identifies challenges. MVAPACK has also enabled us to explore experimental protocols to improve and enhance NMR- and MS-based metabolomics. For examples, we have reported on the application of 31P NMR, 15N NMR, non-uniform sampling, and gadolinium-based paramagnetic relaxation enhancement agents to improve sensitivity and broaden the coverage of the metabolome (i.e., detect phosphorus- or nitrogen-containing metabolites); compared different normalization schemes and multivariate statistical methods to identify an optimal choice; evaluated combining multiple analytical techniques to improve model predictive accuracy; optimized liquid chromatography protocols, collected reference NMR spectra for common metabolites, and investigated the application of machine-learning techniques. Of course, most of these efforts were done as part of broader scientific investigations.
